claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: Vaccine manufacturing using eggs requires specialized facilities, and the ability to scale up egg pro- growth in eggs, a process that can be time consuming, is not always successful, and which can select receptor variants that may not be optimally representative of circulating influenza strains [1,2].
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote directly states that growth in eggs can select for receptor variants, meaning mutations can occur during production that may not match circulating strains, thus potentially reducing vaccine effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: Wood JM, Oxford JS, Dun lea vy U, Newman RW, Major D, Robertson JS. Influenza A (H1 N1) vaccine efficacy in animal models is influenced by two amino acid substitutions in the hemagglutinin molecule. Virology 1989 171 214 21.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This reference is cited in the context of egg-based vaccine production and explicitly states that amino acid substitutions (mutations) in the hemagglutinin molecule can influence vaccine efficacy, supporting the claim that mutations during production can reduce effectiveness.
